instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the Contrast-Enhanced Mammography for helping radiologists in the interpretation of mammographic images of breast lesions?
Output: Statistical and artificial intelligence algorithms were used as spectral feature processing methods in Contrast-Enhanced Mammography for helping radiologists in the interpretation of mammographic images of breast lesions.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the algorithms in the Contrast-Enhanced Mammography for helping radiologists in the interpretation of mammographic images of breast lesions, and how far can this metric go in terms of accuracy?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the algorithms in the study was accuracy. The study reported different accuracy values for different classifications. The classification of malignant versus benign lesions achieved an accuracy of 88.98%. The classification of grading achieved an accuracy of 83.65%. The classification of the presence of the hormone receptor achieved an accuracy of 81.65%. The study also reported higher accuracy values when using multiple features as predictors, with a maximum test accuracy of 95.83% for classifying malignant versus benign lesions. Therefore, the accuracy metric in this study showed promising results in terms of accurately differentiating breast lesions and predicting histological outcomes and molecular subtypes of tumors.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the study evaluating the potentialities of statistical and artificial intelligence algorithms as a tool for helping radiologists in the interpretation of mammographic images of breast lesions?
Output: The machine learning models used to evaluate the performance of the algorithms in the Contrast-Enhanced Mammography for helping radiologists in the interpretation of mammographic images of breast lesions were logistic regression and tree-based algorithms, including classification-tree algorithm and random forest algorithm.

instruction: Can the use of spectroscopic methods enhance the accuracy of statistical and artificial intelligence algorithms in assisting radiologists in interpreting mammographic images of breast lesions, as evaluated in the study?
Output: No, the study specifically focused on the evaluation of radiomics features extracted from Contrast-Enhanced Mammography images, not spectroscopic methods.
